text:
What did women consider important in their lives?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Eugene M. Johnson
Address: Hemelburg
Birthplace: Newcastle, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1913
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Hemelburg
   Where had you been living before that? 2 years in Prince Albert
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 2
   How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Anytime
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Rolled oats, tea, sugar, flour, salt, syrup (ropes)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Quaker
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 3 dollars
   How much did you use graham flour?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? No; far away? Yes; what year?
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat, farina
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
   How did you grind it?
1. INTERESTING QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? 1843.

Where did you settle? In Homesteaders.

How far had you been living there until 2 years ago? 10 miles.

For how many people did you prepare meals? 12.

How far was it to your nearest store? 15 miles.

How often could a visit be made to the store? Anytime.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years? Rolled oats, tea, sugar, B's Powder, Royal MacGillivray Bread, flour, salt, lard, flour, salt.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of wheat flour did you use in the early years? Quebec.

In what quantities did you buy 100 lb. flour? 100 lb.

Was this the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Yes.

How much did you use cracked flour?

Was flour milled locally? No.

Was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Yes.

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal?

Flour?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.

How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 1.0 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 65 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 5 lb.

At what price? 60 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Our cow.

Butter? A.M. eggs? B.M. chickens.

What was the price of butter? Winter $1.00, summer $1.25.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Cottage cheese.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Deer, moose, elk.

How did you get fresh meat? Shot it.

How often did you get fresh meat? Fall, winter, spring.

How did you preserve meat? Canned, deer, etc., but pork was salted, then smoked.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? At one time.

If so what year was it organized? About 1857.

Did you use game? Ducks.

What kinds? Pheasant, prairie chicken, snipe.

For how long? Until we got plenty of our own meat.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Sometimes we just succumbed to fish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh & canned.

Kinds?
1. **MEAT AND FISH**
   
   In what two cities did you make your purchases?  
   What was the quality of the meat purchased?  
   What was the price per pound?  
   Did you purchase any fish?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

2. **BUTTER**
   
   How did you get your butter?  
   What was the quality of the butter purchased?  
   Did you purchase any cheese?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

3. **EGGS**
   
   How did you get your eggs?  
   What was the quality of the eggs purchased?  
   Did you purchase any milk?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

4. **FRESH VEGETABLES**
   
   How did you get your vegetables?  
   What was the quality of the vegetables purchased?  
   Did you purchase any fruit?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

5. **FRUIT**
   
   How did you get your fruit?  
   What was the quality of the fruit purchased?  
   Did you purchase any nuts?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

6. **DRINKS**
   
   How did you get your drinks?  
   What was the quality of the drinks purchased?  
   Did you purchase any tea?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

7. **TOBACCO**
   
   How did you get your tobacco?  
   What was the quality of the tobacco purchased?  
   Did you purchase any cigarettes?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

8. **CLOTHING**
   
   How did you get your clothing?  
   What was the quality of the clothing purchased?  
   Did you purchase any shoes?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

9. **HOUSEHOLD GOODS**
   
   How did you get your household goods?  
   What was the quality of the household goods purchased?  
   Did you purchase any furniture?  
   If so, how much did you pay?

10. **MEDICINE**
    
    How did you get your medicine?  
    What was the quality of the medicine purchased?  
    Did you purchase any pills?  
    If so, how much did you pay?

11. **BOOKS**
    
    How did you get your books?  
    What was the quality of the books purchased?  
    Did you purchase any newspapers?  
    If so, how much did you pay?

12. **OTHER**
    
    How did you get your other items?  
    What was the quality of the other items purchased?  
    Did you purchase any other items?  
    If so, how much did you pay?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? 6.0 cents/1 lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground. Price? 2.0 cents.

What other beverages were used? None.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 3 dollars/bushel.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1913, Cabbage 1914, Carrots 1913, Onions 1913, Turnips 1913, Beets 1913.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 2 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.

What weight? 2 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? By the box.

What was the price of prunes? 25 cents.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

Apples, raisins, currants.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1913.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? Tomatoes 1913.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1914.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

Pork, made into bacon.

To what extent? About 200 quarts fruit, 40 pint meat, 100 pounds beef.

Did you make your own vinegar?

In the earlier years have canned about 700 quarts of fruit, meat, vegetables etc., had about 5 or 6 people in house.
6. **BUYING**

   - What kind of tea did you buy? (Dinner or breakfast)  
     *Tea*
   
   - That other beverages were used how?  
     *Coffee*

7. **VEGETABLES AND FRUITS**

   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel then not up to housekeeping?  
     *Price*

   - If so, where from?  
     *Market*

   - What year did you first grow your own supply for two weeks out of?  
     *1945*

   - Potatoes  
     *1945*  
     *Carrots*  
     *Onions*

   - Turnips  
     *1945*  
     *Beets*  
     *1945*

   - In what quantities did you vary what to carry better?  
     *2*  
     *2*

   - How did you buy potatoes? (In bulk or by the box)?  
     *By the box*

   - What weight?  
     *2 lbs*

   - How did the grocer handle potatoes (by box)?  
     *By the box*

   - What was the price of potatoes?  
     *Price*

   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, prunes, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?  
     *Apples, Nectarines, Currants*

8. **PREPARING**

   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by freezing?  
     *Yes*

   - Other foods?  
     *Yes*

   - That year did you first preserve fruit by canning?  
     *1943*

   - That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?  
     *1943*

   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?  
     *Yes*

   - To what extent?  
     *About 20%*

   - Did you make your own vinegar?  
     *No*

   - In the earlier years have canned about  
     *700 quarts of fruit, meal, vegetables etc.*

   - Had about 5 or 6 acres grown in horses

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Aged

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using starter?

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda?

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? Yes
| Item                  | Price |
|----------------------|-------|
| Soda Blasinate       | 5c    |
| Graham Flour         | 19/3  |
| Brown sugar          | 2     |
| Molasses             | 19/3  |

| Litter                | 1     |
| Toilet soap          | 1     |

| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | 1   |
| Vanilla              | 1     |

**ID. BAKING**

What type of yeast did you use? **Fresh Yeast**

Did you make yeast for your own use? **Yes**

Using starters? **No**

Using hops? **No**

Salt rising? **No**

Did you buy baking powder? **Yes**

Baking soda? **Yes**

Cream of tartar? **Yes**

Did you make your own baking powder? **Yes**

| Food                  | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) **Well**..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? **About 60 yds**...................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **Pail**................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Had a well dug by hand. Last one husband dug with 2 in. pipe 1927, was dug by hand 30 feet 65 with 2 in. pipe. Still good.
11. MEATS PILL & MILK TO THE HOME

| Item          | Year | Approximate price at the market |
|---------------|------|---------------------------------|
| Corned beef   | 1913 | 25 cents per pound              |
| Corned pork   | 1913 | 40 cents per pound              |

If we wanted these had to go to 80¢.

Apples - fresh
Apples - dried
Lettuce
Tomatoes - fresh
Tomatoes - canned

Bananas
Lemons
Oranges

Cornflakes
Other prepared breakfast foods - flour
Bread

Poveshupson
Milwaukee sugar
Sugar
Oats
Wheat
Iceland sugar

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, sluice, dugout) Well.

How was it brought to the house? (pull, barrel, tank) Tank.

For arid water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

Had 3 well dry by hand. Took one well hard up with 2 in. pipe 1927, was dry by hand 30 Feb. 60 feet in auger. Still good.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made my own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal and wood.

Where did you get your fuel? At the off farm.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Had gasoline, bought about 1926, but got burnt very badly and won't use it now. Still use coal oil.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Coal stove.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) Bake oven.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Made in Wisconsin USA.

What year was it purchased? 1906. Price? $40.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China.

When did you first see enamel ware? In England 1906.

Aluminum? 1921. Used it over 20 years steady.

Heater stove bought in 1911 second hand for $9. Still used food. Name Riverside Oak (104) used every winter since.
13. Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? (outside of Ocean)

If you did your own, did you use any other soap?

14. Fuel

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you not your family at all times off farm?

Did you ever change in the use of fuels which have been shown above you

plant started housekeeping, prior to 1926, last fuel burned before

early about 1926, last fuel burned before

wood and what was it over? (oil)

15. Stoves

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or outdoor in the earliest

days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor (irregular) or bake oven? (Give dates)

Price? $10.00

That year was it purchased? (Give date)

That type of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead)

Price? $10.00

For preparing food (chairs, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first use metal utensils? (Give date)

Aluminum? 1926, used for 20 years already

Stove bought in 1911 second hand

Oak (104) used every winter since
16. WRAPPING AND CONTAINING

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

In those days we bought most foods in bulk.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

March 1913 Deer or moose meat Porridge
syrup, etc potatoes

18. What was your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

2 Roasters plum pudding Cake & mar cookies
Potatoes Cabbage salad, Vicia Collini Andy Baird 40yrs Harry Weir
Mrs Pick 36 Mr Pick 35 Red Shapland 24 31
James Taylor 48 my husband
George Cole 32 James Taylor 48 my 30
myself 32

One thing seemed missing. No oranges. Remarkable about it. Harry Weir had one in his pocket. We divided it up among us.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

My husband planted in 1911. Asparagus, it is still on the place, also strawberries planted 1912. Crab apples from Ottawa experimental farm. Some of them still producing and we always had all the vegetables. Potatoes, cabbage, celery, onions, carrots, peas, beans, dried & fresh, cucumbers, tomatoes. The first year I put up canned, over 75 quarts of fruit. Wild strawberries, raspberries, blackberries, were plentiful, but you had to watch out for them. Mosquitoes and flies nearly ate you up, but what did that matter if you had a good cellar full of fruit.
Dear Mr. and Mrs. Smith,

I am writing to express my gratitude for your kind invitation to attend your Christmas dinner. I am honored to be included in such a special event.

Your generosity is truly appreciated. I look forward to spending time with you and enjoying the festivities.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I have not started to rely on purchased food yet. We have always baked our own bread, canned our own fruit, meat etc., and my husband keeps bees so we have all the honey we want.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

When I prepared for my first town dinner, I used to buy a few currants, raisins, candied peel etc. for cake and puddings. So it was no hardship to make them when the time came. Anyone passing needing a meal or bed was always welcome. My neighbour once said, "Don't you use a lot of flour?" So many visitors I had told her when that sack has gone there always seems money for another. She said it must be little the widow's cruse of oil. It failed not, neither did it shrink.
Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible).

I have not started to rely on purchased food yet. We have always taken our own food. I mean we eat food. Canned or our own food too. Have all the money we want.

Please tell other details from your early experiences of buying groceries.

When I purchased food, I often bought canned goods. Racine's canned food, etc., for sale at the store when they were plentiful. So it was no hardship to make them when the time came. Anyone passing needing a meal or bed was always welcome. My neighbour once asked if you use a lot of flour. So many people had said he used that much flour. She paid it back in money. The widow's house of oil must be sold. Neither old or young. It failed out, neither old or young.
I wonder what the trappers would think of today. If they had trapped marmots in 1914, a friend of ours trapped 600 rats for the price of 6 cents each. $36.00 dollars for 600 rats.

One year in 1930, we could not sell rasp (cultivated) only for 10 cents a quart—lovely big one free from insects. I canned nine 245 quarts. Later in fall sold them for 40 cents quart, got my sailors back.

One year we sold dressed pork 2 3/4 cents a lb.

In 1930 food No. 2 wheat was 18 cents a bushel cost 9 cents for threshing, all other labor and seed.

In 1921 fall, a neighbor sold 13 head of cattle. One cow 2 and 3 years old for $75 dollars. One head today would bring that price.

One year had 1400 bushel potatoes sold about 100 bushel in fall 25 cents bushel. 200 more in spring delivered them 25 cents away, 25 cents bushel. Next sold 5 cents bushel.

3 clock wagon load $5 dollars. But they had to come out of the root house. A neighbor had 1,000 bushel white potatoes hocused lovely. Never sold a bushel. But we lived through it all. And never went in debt.

If eggs or butter went down in price when we got to the store, we just crossed off the items, we could do without. How much better than the installment plan no worries about paying bill. We just did not have any.

Yours truly,
Mrs. E. M. Johnson
I wonder what we shipped hereabouts in
of today. If they had shipped hereabouts in
1914, a friend of ours shipped 600 cats for
the price of 6 cents each. 36,000 dollars for
600 cats.

One year in 1930, we could not sell Rasp (cultivated)
only 10 cents a quart. Got my scales back.
Sold them for 40 cents a quart. Got my scales back.
One year we sold dried beans for 25 cents a lb.
In 1921 fall, a crop of 13 head of cattle
Some 2 and 3 years old for $75 dollars. One
head today would buy their price

Last year had 1400 bushel potatoes @ 10¢
about 100 bushel in fall 85¢ cut - crushed
200 more in spring delivered them 25¢ extra
away. 25¢ cut - crushed next fall 5¢ cut - crushed
3 deck wagon load. Next fall they had
to come out of the rent house. A neighbour
had never tried white potatoes before. Lovely
potatoes. Never sold a crushed bush - ever
lived through it all. And never went
in debt.

If egg or butter were down in prices when
we got to the store, we could do without. How
the fellows, we could do without. Plan
much better than the two tall men. Didn't
bother about paying bills. We just didn't
not have any. Yours Truly

Mrs & Mr John
